title: How ministers sealed Thomas Cook's fate by refusing them a bailout
text:
Ministers refused to bail out Thomas Cook because they feared other failing businesses would expect a lifeline from taxpayers.

In a letter to the travel operator's then chief executive Peter Fankhauser, the Government confirmed it would not be rescued.

The missive that sealed Thomas Cook's fate was signed on behalf of Gareth Davies, director general of the Department for Transport, and sent on the evening of Sunday, September 22, after a weekend of failed rescue talks.

Grounded: A letter sent to Thomas Cook's chief exec Dr Peter Fankhauser, signed on behalf of Gareth Davies, head of the Department for Transport, confirmed there would be no rescue

A few hours later, at 4am on Monday morning, the 178-year-old travel company collapsed into liquidation.

In the letter, obtained by ITV News, Davies stated: 'Financial intervention by the Government is on an exceptional basis.

'Any financial assistance would represent [Government] intervention in the commercial market and creates a significant precedent risk to the private sector in future restructurings.'

The Government has used the same so-called 'moral hazard' argument for declining to bail out other big firms, including construction group Carillion – a major government contractor – and British Steel.

Royal Bank of Scotland and Lloyds were rescued during the financial crisis because officials were worried their collapse posed a systemic risk to the economy.

The letter emerged as Thomas Cook's former bosses, including Fankhauser, former chairman Frank Meysman, and former finance chief Sten Daugaard, face questions from MPs this morning over the firm's collapse.

The Commons' Business Committee is likely to pile pressure on bosses to hand back bonuses.

The last three chief executives raked in £35million in the 12 years leading up to the firm's collapse. Among them were Manny Fontenla-Novoa, who amassed £17million between 2007 and 2011.

Executives will also face questions over how the company managed to rack up £1.7billion of debts and whether they could have done more to save it from going under.

The committee is also likely to ask bosses exactly when they knew the company was on the verge of collapse.

It has emerged that executives were told in August by its banks, including RBS, that it needed to raise another £200million for them to support a rescue deal negotiated over the summer.

This crucial development was kept from investors and sparked panic when it was leaked to the media on September 19, just a few days before the travel business collapsed.

Shares in Thomas Cook crashed by more than a fifth on the Friday, before last ditch rescue talks over the weekend.

Swiss businessman Fankhauser, 58, has claimed the banks only insisted that the extra £200million was essential on September 9.
description: A letter sent to the travel giant's then chief exec Dr Peter Fankhauser, and signed on behalf of Gareth Davies, director general of the Department for Transport, confirmed there would be no rescue.
